title: Picasso's Journey
subtitle: Follow the revolutionary artist from Malaga to Paris
introduction: Pablo Picasso lived 91 years and created over 13,500 paintings, plus thousands of sculptures, ceramics, and drawings. Born in Malaga, trained in Barcelona, he conquered Paris and reinvented art multiple times over seven decades. From the Blue Period to Cubism to his late expressionist works, Picasso's journey spans the entire history of modern art.

trail.shortDescription: Where Picasso was born and first picked up a brush
trail.description: Pablo Ruiz Picasso was born on October 25, 1881, in a house on Plaza de la Merced. His father was an art teacher and painter. Young Pablo's talent emerged early; his first word was reportedly 'piz' (short for lápiz, Spanish for pencil). At age 8, he completed his first painting after watching his father paint pigeons.
trail.significance: Picasso's artistic DNA. The Mediterranean light, bullfighting traditions, and Spanish culture of Malaga influenced him throughout his life.

whatToSee.name: Museo Picasso Málaga
whatToSee.address: Palacio de Buenavista, Calle San Agustín, 8
whatToSee.description: Over 200 works spanning Picasso's entire career, donated by his family

whatToSee.name: Picasso's Birthplace
whatToSee.description: The house where Picasso was born, now a museum with family memorabilia and early works

whatToSee.name: Plaza de la Merced
whatToSee.description: The square where Picasso played as a child. A statue of him sits on a bench.

whatToSee.name: Church of Santiago
whatToSee.description: Where Picasso was baptized in 1881

trail.shortDescription: Where teenage Picasso trained and launched his career
trail.description: Picasso's family moved to Barcelona when he was 14. He enrolled at the prestigious La Llotja art school, where his father taught. Within months, he was outpainting his teachers. In the bohemian tavern Els Quatre Gats, he met fellow artists, held his first exhibition, and developed the melancholic style that became his Blue Period.
trail.significance: Barcelona made Picasso an artist. The Blue Period began here after the suicide of his friend Casagemas. The city's avant-garde scene prepared him for Paris.

whatToSee.name: Museu Picasso
whatToSee.description: Over 4,000 works including the complete Las Meninas series. The best collection of his early work.

whatToSee.name: Els Quatre Gats
whatToSee.description: The bohemian café where Picasso had his first exhibition in 1900. Still operating as a restaurant.

whatToSee.name: La Llotja
whatToSee.description: The art school where teenage Picasso studied and amazed his professors

whatToSee.name: Carrer d'Avinyó
whatToSee.description: The street that inspired Les Demoiselles d'Avignon, named after a Barcelona brothel

trail.shortDescription: The bohemian studio where Cubism was born
trail.description: At 23, Picasso moved permanently to Paris, settling in the Bateau-Lavoir, a ramshackle building on Montmartre. In this freezing, cramped studio, surrounded by poets and artists, he created Les Demoiselles d'Avignon (1907), the painting that shattered Western art. With Georges Braque, he invented Cubism, fragmenting reality into geometric planes.
trail.significance: The most revolutionary studio in art history. Cubism emerged here, changing everything. Picasso's Rose and early Cubist periods unfolded in Montmartre.

whatToSee.name: Bateau-Lavoir
whatToSee.description: The studio building where Picasso lived 1904-1909 and painted Les Demoiselles d'Avignon. Destroyed by fire in 1970, rebuilt; a plaque marks the site.

whatToSee.name: Musée de Montmartre
whatToSee.description: Dedicated to the neighborhood's artistic history, with Renoir's former studio and gardens

whatToSee.name: Place du Tertre
whatToSee.description: The square where Picasso and his friends gathered. Still filled with artists today.

whatToSee.name: Le Lapin Agile
whatToSee.description: The cabaret Picasso frequented, which he paid for a meal with a painting (Au Lapin Agile). Still operating.

trail.description: During the Nazi occupation, Picasso refused to flee Paris. He remained in his studio on Rue des Grands-Augustins, where he had painted Guernica in 1937. When German soldiers visited and saw a photo of Guernica, one asked 'Did you do that?' Picasso replied, 'No, you did.' He continued painting defiantly throughout the occupation.
trail.significance: Guernica, Picasso's response to the bombing of a Basque town, became the century's most powerful anti-war statement. His wartime resilience made him a symbol of resistance.

whatToSee.name: 7 Rue des Grands-Augustins
whatToSee.description: Picasso's studio where he painted Guernica and lived during WWII. Private building; plaque on exterior.

whatToSee.name: Musée Picasso Paris
whatToSee.description: The world's largest Picasso collection with over 5,000 works across all periods

whatToSee.name: Café de Flore
whatToSee.description: The legendary café where Picasso, Sartre, and Simone de Beauvoir held court

trail.description: After WWII, Picasso discovered the pottery town of Vallauris and revolutionized ceramics. He created over 4,500 ceramic pieces, from plates to vases to sculptures. His presence revived the local pottery industry. The town made him an honorary citizen, and he created a monumental mural, War and Peace, for a medieval chapel.
trail.significance: Picasso proved there was no artistic medium he couldn't master and transform. Vallauris shows his playful late period and his continued ability to reinvent himself.

whatToSee.name: Musée National Picasso - La Guerre et la Paix
whatToSee.description: A 12th-century chapel housing Picasso's War and Peace murals

whatToSee.name: Man with a Sheep Statue
whatToSee.description: Picasso's bronze sculpture gifted to the town, in the central square

whatToSee.name: Madoura Pottery
whatToSee.description: The pottery workshop where Picasso created ceramics. Many pieces still produced from his original designs.

trail.artworksNote: Most of Picasso's Vallauris ceramics are in private collections or the Musée Picasso Paris.

trail.shortDescription: Picasso's final home and extraordinary last works
trail.description: Picasso spent his last 12 years at Notre-Dame-de-Vie, a farmhouse estate in Mougins overlooking the Mediterranean. Despite his age, he worked furiously, producing over 1,000 paintings and 2,000 drawings. His late works, once dismissed, are now recognized as a final burst of expressive genius.
trail.significance: Picasso worked until two days before his death at 91. The late period shows an artist confronting mortality with undiminished creative fire.

whatToSee.name: Notre-Dame-de-Vie
whatToSee.description: Picasso's final home where he died on April 8, 1973. Private property; visible from the road.

whatToSee.name: Mougins Museum of Classical Art (MACM)
whatToSee.description: Contains a significant collection of Picasso ceramics and works by his contemporaries

whatToSee.name: Old Village of Mougins
whatToSee.description: The medieval hilltop village Picasso loved, with galleries and restaurants

currentLocations.title: Where to See Picasso's Work Today
currentLocations.description: With 13,500+ paintings, Picasso's work fills museums worldwide. These collections are essential:

topMuseums.name: Museo Reina Sofía
topMuseums.note: Home of Guernica, displayed in its own gallery

topMuseums.name: Museu Picasso
topMuseums.note: The world's best collection of early Picasso

topMuseums.name: Museum of Modern Art (MoMA)
topMuseums.note: Houses Les Demoiselles d'Avignon and Three Musicians

topMuseums.name: Museo Picasso Málaga
topMuseums.note: In his birthplace, donated by his family

suggestedItineraries.name: Barcelona Picasso
suggestedItineraries.description: Explore his formative years at the Museu Picasso, Els Quatre Gats, and the Gothic Quarter

suggestedItineraries.name: Picasso's Spain
suggestedItineraries.description: From birthplace Malaga to Barcelona to Madrid's Guernica

suggestedItineraries.name: Paris Cubist Trail
suggestedItineraries.description: Visit Montmartre's Bateau-Lavoir, the Musée Picasso, and Left Bank haunts

suggestedItineraries.name: Côte d'Azur Picasso
suggestedItineraries.description: Explore Picasso's sun-drenched later years in Vallauris and Mougins

suggestedItineraries.name: The Complete Picasso
suggestedItineraries.description: A comprehensive journey through all major Picasso locations

timeline.event: Born in Málaga, Spain on October 25
Family moves to Barcelona; enrolls at La Llotja art school
Paints Science and Charity at age 15
Blue Period begins after friend's suicide
Moves to Paris permanently; settles in Bateau-Lavoir
Paints Les Demoiselles d'Avignon; Cubism begins
Paints Guernica in response to Spanish Civil War bombing
Joins Communist Party after Paris liberation
Settles in Mougins for final years
Dies at Mougins on April 8, aged 91
